template.name: HP Smart Array Monitoring_Backup
template.description: Discover and monitor HP Smart Array Controllers on Windows with PowerShell.

discovery_rule.name: HP Smart Array Controller Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery all HP Smart Array Controllers on the server.

item_prototype.name: Smart Array Controller Battery status
item_prototype.description: {#CTRL.MODEL} with s/n {#CTRL.SN} in slot {#CTRL.SLOT} battery status.

trigger_prototype.name: Smart Array Controller Battery status
trigger_prototype.description: Battery status on controller {#CTRL.MODEL} on state {ITEM.LASTVALUE}.

item_prototype.name: Smart Array Controller Cache status
item_prototype.description: {#CTRL.MODEL} with s/n {#CTRL.SN} in slot {#CTRL.SLOT} cache status.

trigger_prototype.name: Smart Array Controller Cache status
trigger_prototype.description: Cache status on controller {#CTRL.MODEL} on state {ITEM.LASTVALUE}.

item_prototype.name: Smart Array Controller Main status
item_prototype.description: {#CTRL.MODEL} with s/n {#CTRL.SN} in slot {#CTRL.SLOT} main status.

trigger_prototype.name: Smart Array Controller Main status
trigger_prototype.description: Main status of controller {#CTRL.MODEL} on state {ITEM.LASTVALUE}.

discovery_rule.name: HP Smart Array Logical Drives Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discover of all logical drives on Smart Array Controller.

item_prototype.name: Logical Drive {#LD.NUM} Status
item_prototype.description: Status of Logical Drive {#LD.NUM} with capacity of {#LD.CAPACITY}.

trigger_prototype.name: Smart Array Controller Logical Drive {#LD.NUM} status
trigger_prototype.description: Logical Drive {#LD.NUM} with capacity {#LD.CAPACITY} status is {ITEM.LASTVALUE}.

discovery_rule.name: HP Smart Array Physical Drives Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery all physical drives on HP Smart Array Controller.

item_prototype.name: Physical Drive {#PD.NUM} Status
item_prototype.description: Status of Physical Drive {#PD.NUM} on controller in slot {#CTRL.SLOT}.

trigger_prototype.name: Smart Array Controller Physical Drive {#PD.NUM} status
trigger_prototype.description: Physical Drive {#PD.NUM} status is {ITEM.LASTVALUE}.

trigger_prototype.name: BBU is not in optimal state on adapter:{#ADAPTER_ID}
trigger_prototype.description: Backup Battery Unit on RAID adapter is not in operational state. RAID volumes performance can be degraded

trigger_prototype.name: RAID info is outdated on {HOST.NAME}
trigger_prototype.description: RAID INFO not updated more than 35 minutes. Check task scheduler on host and connectivity

item_prototype.name: BBU state of charge on adapter:{#ADAPTER_ID}

trigger_prototype.name: BBU on adapter:{#ADAPTER_ID} charge capacity degraded
RAID Volume Adapter:{#ADAPTER_ID},ID:{#VDRIVE_ID} state is not Optimal

template.name: Template Module Generic SNMPv2_Backups
template.description: Template Module Generic version: 0.15 MIBs used: SNMPv2-MIB

item.name: SNMP traps (fallback)
item.description: Item is used to collect all SNMP traps unmatched by other snmptrap items

item.name: Device contact details
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The textual identification of the contact person for this managed node, together with information on how to contact this person. If no contact information is known, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: Device description
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB A textual description of the entity. This value should include the full name and version identification of the system's hardware type, software operating-system, and networking software.

item.name: Device location
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The physical location of this node (e.g., `telephone closet, 3rd floor'). If the location is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: Device name
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB An administratively-assigned name for this managed node.By convention, this is the node's fully-qualified domain name. If the name is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: System object ID
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The vendor's authoritative identification of the network management subsystem contained in the entity. This value is allocated within the SMI enterprises subtree (1.3.6.1.4.1) and provides an easy and unambiguous means for determining`what kind of box' is being managed. For example, if vendor`Flintstones, Inc.' was assigned the subtree1.3.6.1.4.1.4242, it could assign the identifier 1.3.6.1.4.1.4242.1.1 to its `Fred Router'.

item.name: Device uptime
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The time (in hundredths of a second) since the network management portion of the system was last re-initialized.

trigger.name: {HOST.NAME} has been restarted
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. The device uptime is less than 10 minutes

trigger.name: No SNMP data collection
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. SNMP is not available for polling. Please check device connectivity and SNMP settings.

trigger.name: Unavailable by ICMP ping
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Last three attempts returned timeout. Please check device connectivity.

dependency.name: High ICMP ping loss
dependency.expression: {Template Module ICMP Ping_Backups:icmppingloss.min(5m)}>{$ICMP_LOSS_WARN} and {Template Module ICMP Ping_Backups:icmppingloss.min(5m)}<100

template.template: Template Module Windows CPU by Zabbix agent_Backup
template.name: Template Module Windows CPU by Zabbix agent_Backup

item.name: CPU DPC time
item.description: Processor DPC time is the time that a single processor spent receiving and servicing deferred procedure calls (DPCs). DPCs are interrupts that run at a lower priority than standard interrupts. % DPC Time is a component of % Privileged Time because DPCs are executed in privileged mode. If a high % DPC Time is sustained, there may be a processor bottleneck or an application or hardware related issue that can significantly diminish overall system performance.

item.name: CPU interrupt time
item.description: The Processor Information\% Interrupt Time is the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interrupts during sample intervals. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, disk drivers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. This is an easy way to identify a potential hardware failure. This should never be higher than 20%.

trigger.name: CPU interrupt time is too high (over {$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger.description: "The CPU Interrupt Time in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}%." The Processor Information\% Interrupt Time is the time the processor spends receiving and servicing hardware interrupts during sample intervals. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, disk drivers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. This is an easy way to identify a potential hardware failure. This should never be higher than 20%.

item.name: CPU privileged time
item.description: The Processor Information\% Privileged Time counter shows the percent of time that the processor is spent executing in Kernel (or Privileged) mode. Privileged mode includes services interrupts inside Interrupt Service Routines (ISRs), executing Deferred Procedure Calls (DPCs), Device Driver calls and other kernel-mode functions of the Windows® Operating System.

trigger.name: CPU privileged time is too high (over {$CPU.PRIV.CRIT.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger.description: The CPU privileged time in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$CPU.PRIV.CRIT.MAX}%.

dependency.name: CPU interrupt time is too high (over {$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}% for 5m)
dependency.expression: {Template Module Windows CPU by Zabbix agent_Backup:perf_counter["\Processor Information(_total)\% Interrupt Time"].min(5m)}>{$CPU.INTERRUPT.CRIT.MAX}

item.name: CPU user time
item.description: The Processor Information\% User Time counter shows the percent of time that the processor(s) is spent executing in User mode.

item.name: Context switches per second
item.description: Context Switches/sec is the combined rate at which all processors on the computer are switched from one thread to another. Context switches occur when a running thread voluntarily relinquishes the processor, is preempted by a higher priority ready thread, or switches between user-mode and privileged (kernel) mode to use an Executive or subsystem service. It is the sum of Thread\\Context Switches/sec for all threads running on all processors in the computer and is measured in numbers of switches. There are context switch counters on the System and Thread objects. This counter displays the difference between the values observed in the last two samples, divided by the duration of the sample interval.

item.name: CPU queue length
item.description: The Processor Queue Length shows the number of threads that are observed as delayed in the processor Ready Queue and are waiting to be executed.

trigger.name: CPU queue length is too high (over {$CPU.QUEUE.CRIT.MAX} for 5m)
trigger.description: The CPU Queue Length in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$CPU.QUEUE.CRIT.MAX}.

item.name: CPU utilization
item.description: CPU utilization in %

trigger.name: High CPU utilization (over {$CPU.UTIL.CRIT}% for 5m)
trigger.description: CPU utilization is too high. The system might be slow to respond.

macro.description: The critical threshold of the % Interrupt Time counter.
The threshold of the % Privileged Time counter.
The threshold of the Processor Queue Length counter.
The critical threshold of the CPU utilization in %.

This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.

template.name: Template Module Windows generic by Zabbix agent_Backup

item.name: Number of threads
item.description: The number of threads used by all running processes.

item.name: Number of processes
item.description: The number of processes.

item.name: System local time
item.description: System local time of the host.

trigger.name: System time is out of sync (diff with Zabbix server > {$SYSTEM.FUZZYTIME.MAX}s)
trigger.description: The host system time is different from the Zabbix server time.

item.name: Operating system architecture
item.description: Operating system architecture of the host.

item.name: System description
item.description: System description of the host.

macro.description: The threshold for difference of system time in seconds.

template.template: Template Module Windows memory by Zabbix agent_Backup
template.name: Template Module Windows memory by Zabbix agent_Backup

item.name: Cache bytes
item.description: Cache Bytes is the sum of the Memory\\System Cache Resident Bytes, Memory\\System Driver Resident Bytes, Memory\\System Code Resident Bytes, and Memory\\Pool Paged Resident Bytes counters. This counter displays the last observed value only; it is not an average.

item.name: Free system page table entries
item.description: This indicates the number of page table entries not currently in use by the system. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak or you running out of memory.

trigger.name: Number of free system page table entries is too low (less {$MEM.PAGE_TABLE_CRIT.MIN} for 5m)
trigger.description: The Memory Free System Page Table Entries is less than {$MEM.PAGE_TABLE_CRIT.MIN} for 5 minutes. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak.

item.name: Memory page faults per second
item.description: Page Faults/sec is the average number of pages faulted per second. It is measured in number of pages faulted per second because only one page is faulted in each fault operation, hence this is also equal to the number of page fault operations. This counter includes both hard faults (those that require disk access) and soft faults (where the faulted page is found elsewhere in physical memory.) Most processors can handle large numbers of soft faults without significant consequence. However, hard faults, which require disk access, can cause significant delays.

item.name: Memory pages per second
item.description: This measures the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

trigger.name: The Memory Pages/sec is too high (over {$MEM.PAGE_SEC.CRIT.MAX} for 5m)
trigger.description: The Memory Pages/sec in the last 5 minutes exceeds {$MEM.PAGE_SEC.CRIT.MAX}. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

item.name: Memory pool non-paged
item.description: This measures the size, in bytes, of the non-paged pool. This is an area of system memory for objects that cannot be written to disk but instead must remain in physical memory as long as they are allocated. There is a possible memory leak if the value is greater than 175MB (or 100MB with the /3GB switch). A typical Event ID 2019 is recorded in the system event log.

item.name: Free swap space
item.description: The free space of swap volume/file in bytes.

item.name: Free swap space in %
item.description: The free space of swap volume/file in percent.

item.name: Total swap space
item.description: The total space of swap volume/file in bytes.

item.name: Total memory
item.description: Total memory in Bytes

item.name: Used memory
item.description: Used memory in Bytes

item.name: Memory utilization
item.description: Memory utilization in %

trigger.name: High memory utilization ( >{$MEMORY.UTIL.MAX}% for 5m)
trigger.description: The system is running out of free memory.

macro.description: The warning threshold of the Memory Pages/sec counter.
The warning threshold of the Free System Page Table Entries counter.
The warning threshold of the Memory util item.
The warning threshold of the minimum free swap.

template.template: Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup
template.name: Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup

item.name: Network interfaces WMI get
item.description: Raw data of win32_networkadapter.

discovery_rule.name: Network interfaces discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of installed network interfaces.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: The number of incoming packets dropped on the network interface.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets with errors
item_prototype.description: The number of incoming packets with errors on the network interface.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits received
item_prototype.description: Incoming traffic on the network interface.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Outbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: The number of outgoing packets dropped on the network interface.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Outbound packets with errors
item_prototype.description: The number of outgoing packets with errors on the network interface.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits sent
item_prototype.description: Outgoing traffic on the network interface.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Speed
item_prototype.description: Estimated bandwidth of the network interface if any.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Operational status
item_prototype.description: The operational status of the network interface.

trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
trigger_prototype.description:
This trigger expression works as follows: 1. Can be triggered if operations status is down. 2. {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 - user can redefine Context macro to value - 0. That marks this interface as not important. No new trigger will be fired if this interface is down. 3. {TEMPLATE_NAME:METRIC.diff()}=1) - trigger fires only if operational status was up(1) sometime before. (So, do not fire 'ethernal off' interfaces.)
WARNING: if closed manually - won't fire again on next poll, because of .diff.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Interface type
item_prototype.description: The type of the network interface.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].change()}<0 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].last()}>0 and ( {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.type["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=6 or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.type["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=7 or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.type["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=11 or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.type["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=62 or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.type["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=69 or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.type["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=117 ) and ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].last()}<>2)
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].change()}>0 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].prev()}>0) or ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=2)
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototype.description: This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Ack to close.

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=2 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].diff()}=1)

trigger_prototype.expression: ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.in["{#IFNAME}"].avg(15m)}>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*{Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].last()} or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.out["{#IFNAME}"].avg(15m)}>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*{Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].last()}) and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].last()}>0
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.in["{#IFNAME}"].avg(15m)}<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*{Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].last()} and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.out["{#IFNAME}"].avg(15m)}<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*{Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.speed["{#IFNAME}"].last()}
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High bandwidth usage ( > {$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}% )
trigger_prototype.description: The network interface utilization is close to its estimated maximum bandwidth.

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=2 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].diff()}=1)

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.in["{#IFNAME}",errors].min(5m)}>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} or {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.out["{#IFNAME}",errors].min(5m)}>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.in["{#IFNAME}",errors].max(5m)}<{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}*0.8 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.out["{#IFNAME}",errors].max(5m)}<{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}*0.8
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High error rate ( > {$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: Recovers when below 80% of {$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} threshold

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].last()}=2 and {Template Module Windows network by Zabbix agent_Backup:net.if.status["{#IFNAME}"].diff()}=1)

Use this template for agents reachable from Zabbix server/proxy (passive mode).

Zabbix agent ping
item.description: The agent always returns 1 for this item. It could be used in combination with nodata() for availability check.

item.description: Monitoring agent availability status

trigger.name: Zabbix agent is not available (for {$AGENT.TIMEOUT})
trigger.description: For passive only agents, host availability is used with {$AGENT.TIMEOUT} as time threshold.

macro.description: Timeout after which agent is considered unavailable. Works only for agents reachable from Zabbix server/proxy (passive mode).

You can discuss this template or leave feedback on our forum https://www.zabbix.com/forum/zabbix-suggestions-and-feedback/387224-discussion-thread-for-official-zabbix-template-for-windows

discovery_rule.description: Discovery of network interfaces as defined in global regular expression "Network interfaces for discovery".

template.name: Template Server HP iLO SNMPv2_Backups
template.description: Template Server HP iLO version: 0.15 Overview: for HP iLO adapters that support SNMP get. Or via operating system, using SNMP HP subagent MIBs used: CPQSINFO-MIB CPQHLTH-MIB CPQIDA-MIB

item.name: System: Temperature status
item.description: MIB: CPQHLTH-MIB This value specifies the overall condition of the system's thermal environment. This value will be one of the following: other(1) Temperature could not be determined. ok(2) The temperature sensor is within normal operating range. degraded(3) The temperature sensor is outside of normal operating range. failed(4) The temperature sensor detects a condition that could permanently damage the system.

item.name: Hardware model name
item.description: MIB: CPQSINFO-MIB The machine product name.The name of the machine used in this system.

item.name: Hardware serial number
item.description: MIB: CPQSINFO-MIB The serial number of the physical system unit. The string will be empty if the system does not report the serial number function.

trigger.name: Device has been replaced (new serial number received)
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Device serial number has changed. Ack to close

item.name: Overall system health status
item.description: MIB: CPQSINFO-MIB The overall condition. This object represents the overall status of the server information represented by this MIB.

trigger.name: System status is in critical state
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the device for errors

trigger.name: System status is in warning state
trigger.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the device for warnings

dependency.name: System status is in critical state

discovery_rule.name: Array Controller Cache Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Scanning table of Array controllers: CPQIDA-MIB::cpqDaAccelTable

item_prototype.name: #{#CACHE_CNTRL_INDEX}: Disk array cache controller battery status
item_prototype.description:
MIB: CPQIDA-MIB Cache Module Board Backup Power Status. This monitors the status of each backup power source on the board. The backup power source can only recharge when the system has power applied. The type of backup power source used is indicated by cpqDaAccelBackupPowerSource. The following values are valid: Other (1) Indicates that the instrument agent does not recognize backup power status. You may need to update your software.
Ok (2) The backup power source is fully charged.
Recharging (3) The array controller has one or more cache module backup power sources that are recharging. Cache module operations such as Battery/Flash Backed Write Cache, Expansion, Extension and Migration are temporarily suspended until the backup power source is fully charged. Cache module operations will automatically resume when charging is complete.
Failed (4) The battery pack is below the sufficient voltage level and has not recharged in 36 hours. Your Cache Module board needs to be serviced.
Degraded (5) The battery is still operating, however, one of the batteries in the pack has failed to recharge properly. Your Cache Module board should be serviced as soon as possible.
NotPresent (6) A backup power source is not present on the cache module board. Some controllers do not have backup power sources.
Capacitor Failed (7) The flash backed cache module capacitor is below the sufficient voltage level and has not recharged in 10 minutes. Your Cache Module board needs to be serviced.

trigger_prototype.name: #{#CACHE_CNTRL_INDEX}: Disk array cache controller battery is in critical state!
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the device for faults

trigger_prototype.name: #{#CACHE_CNTRL_INDEX}: Disk array cache controller battery is in warning state
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the device for faults

dependency.name: #{#CACHE_CNTRL_INDEX}: Disk array cache controller battery is in critical state!
dependency.expression: {Template Server HP iLO SNMPv2_Backups:system.hw.diskarray.cache.battery.status[cpqDaAccelBattery.{#SNMPINDEX}].count(#1,{$DISK_ARRAY_CACHE_BATTERY_CRIT_STATUS:"failed"},eq)}=1 or {Template Server HP iLO SNMPv2_Backups:system.hw.diskarray.cache.battery.status[cpqDaAccelBattery.{#SNMPINDEX}].count(#1,{$DISK_ARRAY_CACHE_BATTERY_CRIT_STATUS:"capacitorFailed"},eq)}=1

item_prototype.name: #{#CACHE_CNTRL_INDEX}: Disk array cache controller status
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQIDA-MIB Cache Module/Operations Status. This describes the status of the cache module and/or cache operations. Note that for some controller models, a cache module board that physically attaches to the controller or chipset may not be an available option.

trigger_prototype.name: #{#CACHE_CNTRL_INDEX}: Disk array cache controller is in critical state!
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the device for faults

trigger_prototype.name: #{#CACHE_CNTRL_INDEX}: Disk array cache controller is in warning state
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the device for faults

dependency.name: #{#CACHE_CNTRL_INDEX}: Disk array cache controller is in critical state!

trigger_prototype.name: #{#CACHE_CNTRL_INDEX}: Disk array cache controller is not in optimal state
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the device for faults

dependency.name: #{#CACHE_CNTRL_INDEX}: Disk array cache controller is in critical state!
#{#CACHE_CNTRL_INDEX}: Disk array cache controller is in warning state
dependency.expression: {Template Server HP iLO SNMPv2_Backups:system.hw.diskarray.cache.status[cpqDaAccelStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].count(#1,{$DISK_ARRAY_CACHE_WARN_STATUS:"invalid"},eq)}=1 or {Template Server HP iLO SNMPv2_Backups:system.hw.diskarray.cache.status[cpqDaAccelStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].count(#1,{$DISK_ARRAY_CACHE_WARN_STATUS:"cacheModDegradedFailsafeSpeed"},eq)}=1 or {Template Server HP iLO SNMPv2_Backups:system.hw.diskarray.cache.status[cpqDaAccelStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].count(#1,{$DISK_ARRAY_CACHE_WARN_STATUS:"cacheReadCacheNotMapped"},eq)}=1 or {Template Server HP iLO SNMPv2_Backups:system.hw.diskarray.cache.status[cpqDaAccelStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].count(#1,{$DISK_ARRAY_CACHE_WARN_STATUS:"cacheModFlashMemNotAttached"},eq)}=1

discovery_rule.name: Array Controller Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Scanning table of Array controllers: CPQIDA-MIB::cpqDaCntlrTable

item_prototype.name: {#CNTLR_LOCATION}: Disk array controller model
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQIDA-MIB Array Controller Model. The type of controller card.

item_prototype.name: {#CNTLR_LOCATION}: Disk array controller status
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQIDA-MIB This value represents the overall condition of this controller, and any associated logical drives,physical drives, and array accelerators.

trigger_prototype.name: {#CNTLR_LOCATION}: Disk array controller is in critical state
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the device for faults

trigger_prototype.name: {#CNTLR_LOCATION}: Disk array controller is in warning state
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the device for faults

dependency.name: {#CNTLR_LOCATION}: Disk array controller is in critical state

discovery_rule.name: FAN Discovery
discovery_rule.description: CPQHLTH-MIB::cpqHeFltTolFanCondition

item_prototype.name: Fan {#SNMPINDEX}: Fan status
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQHLTH-MIB The condition of the fan. This value will be one of the following: other(1) Fan status detection is not supported by this system or driver. ok(2) The fan is operating properly. degraded(2) A redundant fan is not operating properly. failed(4) A non-redundant fan is not operating properly.

trigger_prototype.name: Fan {#SNMPINDEX}: Fan is in critical state
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the fan unit

trigger_prototype.name: Fan {#SNMPINDEX}: Fan is in warning state
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the fan unit

dependency.name: Fan {#SNMPINDEX}: Fan is in critical state

discovery_rule.name: Physical Disk Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Scanning table of physical drive entries CPQIDA-MIB::cpqDaPhyDrvTable.

item_prototype.name: {#DISK_LOCATION}: Physical disk media type
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQIDA-MIB Drive Array Physical Drive Media Type.The following values are defined: other(1) The instrument agent is unable to determine the physical drive’s media type. rotatingPlatters(2) The physical drive media is composed of rotating platters. solidState(3) The physical drive media is composed of solid state electronics.

item_prototype.name: {#DISK_LOCATION}: Physical disk model name
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQIDA-MIB Physical Drive Model.This is a text description of the physical drive. The text that appears depends upon who manufactured the drive and the drive type. If a drive fails, note the model to identify the type of drive necessary for replacement. If a model number is not present, you may not have properly initialized the drive array to which the physical drive is attached for monitoring.

item_prototype.name: {#DISK_LOCATION}: Physical disk serial number
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQIDA-MIB Physical Drive Serial Number. This is the serial number assigned to the physical drive. This value is based upon the serial number as returned by the SCSI inquiry command but may have been modified due to space limitations. This can be used for identification purposes.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISK_LOCATION}: Disk has been replaced (new serial number received)
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Disk serial number has changed. Ack to close

item_prototype.name: {#DISK_LOCATION}: Disk size
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQIDA-MIB Physical Drive Size in MB. This is the size of the physical drive in megabytes. This value is calculated using the value 1,048,576 (2^20) as a megabyte. Drive manufacturers sometimes use the number 1,000,000 as a megabyte when giving drive capacities so this value may differ from the advertised size of a drive. This field is only applicable for controllers which support SCSI drives, and therefore is not supported by the IDA or IDA-2 controllers. The field will contain 0xFFFFFFFF if the drive capacity cannot be calculated or if the controller does not support SCSI drives.

item_prototype.name: {#DISK_LOCATION}: Physical disk S.M.A.R.T. status
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQIDA-MIB Physical Drive S.M.A.R.T Status.The following values are defined: other(1) The agent is unable to determine if the status of S.M.A.R.T predictive failure monitoring for this drive. ok(2) Indicates the drive is functioning properly. replaceDrive(3) Indicates that the drive has a S.M.A.R.T predictive failure error and should be replaced.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISK_LOCATION}: Physical disk S.M.A.R.T. failed
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Disk probably requires replacement.

item_prototype.name: {#DISK_LOCATION}: Physical disk status
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQIDA-MIB Physical Drive Status. This shows the status of the physical drive. The following values are valid for the physical drive status: other (1) Indicates that the instrument agent does not recognize the drive. You may need to upgrade your instrument agent and/or driver software. ok (2) Indicates the drive is functioning properly. failed (3) Indicates that the drive is no longer operating and should be replaced. predictiveFailure(4) Indicates that the drive has a predictive failure error and should be replaced.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISK_LOCATION}: Physical disk failed
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check physical disk for warnings or errors

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISK_LOCATION}: Physical disk is in warning state
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check physical disk for warnings or errors

discovery_rule.name: PSU Discovery
discovery_rule.description: CPQHLTH-MIB::cpqHeFltTolPowerSupplyStatus

item_prototype.name: Chassis {#CHASSIS_NUM}, bay {#BAY_NUM}: Power supply status
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQHLTH-MIB The condition of the power supply. This value will be one of the following: other(1) The status could not be determined or not present. ok(2) The power supply is operating normally. degraded(3) A temperature sensor, fan or other power supply component is outside of normal operating range. failed(4) A power supply component detects a condition that could permanently damage the system.

trigger_prototype.name: Chassis {#CHASSIS_NUM}, bay {#BAY_NUM}: Power supply is in critical state
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the power supply unit for errors

trigger_prototype.name: Chassis {#CHASSIS_NUM}, bay {#BAY_NUM}: Power supply is in warning state
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the power supply unit for errors

dependency.name: Chassis {#CHASSIS_NUM}, bay {#BAY_NUM}: Power supply is in critical state

discovery_rule.name: Temperature Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Scanning table of Temperature Sensor Entries: CPQHLTH-MIB::cpqHeTemperatureTable

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPINDEX}: Temperature sensor location
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQHLTH-MIB This specifies the location of the temperature sensor present in the system.

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPINDEX}: Temperature
item_prototype.description: MIB: CPQHLTH-MIB Temperature readings of testpoint: {#SNMPINDEX}

trigger_prototype.name: {#SNMPINDEX}: Temperature is above critical threshold: >{$TEMP_CRIT:"{#SNMPINDEX}"}
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. This trigger uses temperature sensor values as well as temperature sensor status if available

trigger_prototype.name: {#SNMPINDEX}: Temperature is above warning threshold: >{$TEMP_WARN:"{#SNMPINDEX}"}
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. This trigger uses temperature sensor values as well as temperature sensor status if available

trigger_prototype.name: {#SNMPINDEX}: Temperature is too low: <{$TEMP_CRIT_LOW:"{#SNMPINDEX}"}
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}.

discovery_rule.name: Virtual Disk Discovery
discovery_rule.description: CPQIDA-MIB::cpqDaLogDrvTable

item_prototype.name: Disk {#SNMPINDEX}({#DISK_NAME}): Layout type
item_prototype.description: Logical Drive Fault Tolerance. This shows the fault tolerance mode of the logical drive.

item_prototype.name: Disk {#SNMPINDEX}({#DISK_NAME}): Disk size
item_prototype.description: Logical Drive Size. This is the size of the logical drive in megabytes. This value is calculated using the value 1,048,576 (2^20) as a megabyte. Drive manufacturers sometimes use the number 1,000,000 as a megabyte when giving drive capacities so this value may differ from the advertised size of a drive.

item_prototype.name: Disk {#SNMPINDEX}({#DISK_NAME}): Status
item_prototype.description: Logical Drive Status.

trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check virtual disk for warnings or errors

trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check virtual disk for warnings or errors

trigger.expression: {Template Module Windows memory by Zabbix agent_Backup:system.swap.size[,pfree].min(5m)}<{$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN} and {Template Module Windows memory by Zabbix agent_Backup:system.swap.size[,total].last()}>0
trigger.name: High swap space usage ( less than {$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN}% free)
trigger.description: This trigger is ignored, if there is no swap configured
